children.subject: Doesn't directly answer your question and I haven't taken these classes, but Ranade is teaching 127 this semester. I'd expect the class to be a lot better-run.
Thank you so much for this answer.
+1 to this answer. I was having doubts about taking 126 instead of 127 as well but this is very encouraging and insightful.
I gave this earlier response...if you two are taking 126 I posted the textbook and study material on the 126 spring 2019 piazza

Don't worry, just because you currently feel more comfortable with using linear algebra than probability to model problems doesn't mean EE 127 & a host of other courses at Cal can't make you feel horrible about your linear algebra skills ;-)

But seriously, take 126, dedicate the ungodly 30 or 40 hours a week you'll need on that course and come away with something deep and true. That course is amazing -- read the Walrand supplemental and you will feel one with the heavens. I know that doesn't make a ton of sense, but consider this. When you were a little kid, you probably knew math rather well [after all, you're here]. You probably knew various geometric shortcuts, and they were a source of humor and curiosity. These were good things, and you could be clever about them [not unlike how linear algebra has all these beautiful properties itself]. EE 126 can show you that same feeling, for lack of a better description, of a language and interaction with the world in a manner few things, not just courses or textbooks or blah blah blah can, but in a manner few things ever can give you in your lifetime.

I think if you are brutally honest with yourself, and want to be something completely different than what you are right now [and I don't mean this sardonically, I am simply asking if you are seeking a deep personal change], take 126. 

Likewise 127 is just as hard lmaooooo, if lower divs were hard, upper divs may not be 'grade-hard' but conceptually, are mind-shattering. It's like the logarithmic Richter scale -- ironically, at some point or another it all means the same thing.

history.content:
I'm currently enrolled for EE126 right now. I have some concerns because I know that my probability is not super strong. I'm worried that I'm ill prepared because of the pace and depth of the material covered.

Another class that I might want to take if I don't take EE126 is EE127 because I feel more comfortable with linear algebra. However, I've heard that EE127 isn't super well run and is more 'shallow' (idk what they mean exactly, just what I've read) than material in EE126. 

These courses are foundational for ml, signal processing, etc. which is what I might want to pursue, so I want to take at least one of these courses before taking CS189 next semester. 

Can anyone who has taken these classes give some insight? That would be super helpful!
history.subject: EE126 vs EE127
